prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

head.headtext: Specific factors articulated by the Panel—Views of the parties

para.paratext: The Panel gives some weight to the views of the parties on the question of whether transfer should be ordered. In one case the Panel concluded that the fact that all parties agreed on the transfer question made its decision an “easy one.”[1] The preferences of the parties is not determinative, for the Panel can transfer over the objection of all parties,[2] and may decline to transfer cases even if all parties are in agreement.[3] Indeed, the Panel has noted that it has “institutional responsibility beyond the parties” in denying transfer even if all parties agree to it.[4] Nonetheless, the Panel seeks to minimize the disruption its rulings will have on the choices for management of litigation made by the parties, and gives the parties' preferences definite consideration. The unanimous or nearly unanimous opposition of numerous parties militates strongly against transfer.[5] The agreement of the parties in the case or cases to be transferred, regardless of the views of the parties in cases already pending in the transferee district, may also be an important factor.[6] Failure to object may also support transfer.[7] It is fairly common for the parties to agree on centralization but have strong (and divergent) preferences as to where the centralization should occur.[8]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See In re: Opana ER Antitrust Litigation, 65 F. Supp. 3d 1408 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re: General Motors LLC Ignition Switch Litigation, 26 F. Supp. 3d 1390 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Brown Co. Securities Litigation, 325 F. Supp. 307, 308 (J.P.M.L. 1971). Accord In re Aqua Dots Products Liability Litigation, 545 F. Supp. 2d 1369 (J.P.M.L. 2008) (transfer ordered; all parties agree on transfer); In re Chicken Broiler Antitrust Litigation, 411 F. Supp. 788 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Warhead Explosion Aboard USS Newport News on October 1, 1972, 411 F. Supp. 790 (J.P.M.L. 1976); In re Palizzio, Inc. Antitrust Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 241 (J.P.M.L. 1976). See also In re Global Crossing Ltd. Securities Litigation, 341 F. Supp. 2d 1357 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Currency Conversion Fee Antitrust Litigation, 176 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2001); In re America Online, Inc., 162 F. Supp. 2d 690 (J.P.M.L. 2001).
See, e.g., In re Natural Gas Liquids Regulation Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 665 (J.P.M.L. 1977).

In re Royal American Industries, Inc. Securities Litigation, 407 F. Supp. 242 (J.P.M.L. 1976). See also In re Kmart Corporation Customer Data Security Breach Litigation, 109 F. Supp. 3d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2015).

In re UBS Financial Services, Inc., Wage and Hour Employment Practices Litigation, 818 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2011); In re Nutella Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 804 F. Supp. 2d 1374, 1375 (J.P.M.L. 2011), citing In re Equinox Fitness Wage and Hour Employment Practices Litigation, 764 F. Supp. 2d 1347 (J.P.M.L. 2011). See also In re Dollar Tree Stores, Inc., Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) and Wage and Hour Litigation, 829 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (same institutional responsibility as to selection of transferee district different from one preferred by all parties).

See, e.g., In re Women's Clothing Antitrust Litigation, 455 F. Supp. 1388, 1391 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re “Lite Beer” Trademark Litigation, 437 F. Supp. 754, 755 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Natural Gas Liquids Regulation Litigation, 434 F. Supp. 665, 667 (J.P.M.L. 1977); In re Asbestos and Asbestos Insulation Material Products Liability Litigation, 431 F. Supp. 906, 909 (J.P.M.L. 1977).

See In re Optical Disk Drive Products Antitrust Litigation, 701 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2010); In re Fretted Musical Instruments Antitrust Litigation, 657 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Plasma-Derivative Protein Therapies Antitrust Litigation, 657 F. Supp. 2d 1371 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Air Crash Near Clarence Center, New York, on February 12, 2009, 655 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Blood Reagents Antitrust Litigation, 652 F. Supp. 2d 1363 (J.P.M.L. 2009); In re Veeco Instruments Inc. Securities Litigation, 387 F. Supp. 2d 1365 (J.P.M.L. 2005); In re Pfizer Ins. Securities, Derivative & ERISA Litigation, 374 F. Supp. 2d 1348, 1349 (J.P.M.L. 2005) (Panel notes “general agreement” among parties that some form of centralization appropriate); In re Philadelphia Life Ins. Co. Sales Practices Litigation, 149 F. Supp. 2d 937 (J.P.M.L. 2001).

See, e.g., In re: Michaels Stores, Inc., Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) Litigation, 96 F. Supp. 3d 1380 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: Syngenta AG MIR162 Corn Litigation, 65 F. Supp. 3d 1401 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014) (no party opposes centralization); In re Novartis Wage and Hour Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2006) (Panel notes transfer motion is unopposed); In re Rio Hair Naturalizer Products Liability Litigation, 904 F. Supp. 1407 (J.P.M.L. 1995). In In re Seroquel Products Liability Litigation, 542 F. Supp. 2d 1366, 1367 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2008), the Panel stated that the non-response of the plaintiffs constituted “apparent acquiescence.”

See In re: GAF Elk Cross Timbers Decking Marketing, Sales Practices and Products Liability Litigation, 65 F. Supp. 3d 1407 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re: Home Depot, Inc. Customer Data Security Breach Litigation., 65 F. Supp. 3d 1398 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re: Blue Buffalo Co., Ltd., Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 53 F. Supp. 3d 1385 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re: Pre-Filled Propane Tank Antitrust Litigation, 53 F. Supp. 3d 1383 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Solodyn (Minocycline Hydrochloride) Antitrust Litigation, 999 F. Supp. 2d 1383 (J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Collecto, Inc., Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) Litigation, 999 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Cast Iron Soil Pipe and Fittings Antitrust Litigation, 999 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2014); In re Columbia and Snake River Dams Clean Water Act Litigation, 987 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Credit Default Swaps Antitrust Litigation, 978 F. Supp. 2d 1374 (J.P.M.L. 2013); In re Monsanto Co. Genetically-Engineered Wheat Litigation, 978 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2013).
